# Dataset
***
In this document we will consider the night price of several Airbnb appartements. This dataset is quite basic and looks like this
Data provided by the [Stockholm International Peace Research Institute](http://armstrade.sipri.org/armstrade/page/toplist.php). Available at .csv format here.

```{r, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
# Libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(hrbrthemes)

# Load dataset from github
data <- read.table("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/holtzy/data_to_viz/master/Example_dataset/1_OneNum.csv", header=TRUE)
```




# Option 1: Histogram
***

No wayyy

```{r, fig.align="center"}
data %>%
  filter( price<300 ) %>%
  ggplot( aes(x=price)) +
    stat_bin(breaks=seq(0,300,10), fill="#69b3a2", color="#e9ecef", alpha=0.9) +
    ggtitle("Night price distribution of Airbnb appartements") +
    theme_ipsum()
```

Note that it is really important to play with the size of the bins during your exploratory analysis. Let's check what happens if we split prices by bins of 2 euros instead of 10:

```{r, fig.align="center"}
data %>%
  filter( price<300 ) %>%
  ggplot( aes(x=price)) +
    stat_bin(breaks=seq(0,300,1), fill="#69b3a2", color="#e9ecef", alpha=0.9) +
    ggtitle("Night price distribution of Airbnb appartements") +
    theme_ipsum()


```

Ouch, this is a very different picture. What's going on?



# Option 2: Density
***

No wayyy

```{r, fig.align="center"}
data %>%
  filter( price<300 ) %>%
  ggplot( aes(x=price)) +
    geom_density(fill="#69b3a2", color="#e9ecef", alpha=0.7) +
    ggtitle("Night price distribution of Airbnb appartements") +
    theme_ipsum()
```
